Paper 1 - Differential Phase Shift Keying-Aided Multi-Mode Chirp Spread Spectrum Modulation

Modulation

The conventional CSS incorporates N symbols (or frequency shifts), which is divided into P groups, each containing symbols, implying bits. Then, the un-chirped signals is denoted by [f1(n), …, fP(n)] with .

Then, M-ary phase shift keying symbols are further modified by differential phase shift keying as modulated onto these un-chirped signals, yielding Then, the superimposed un-chirped signal is given by , of which the modulation onto chirps is given by , where v ∈ {u, d} with and , identified by a single bit bv.

Therefore, the number of employed bits is .

Demodulation

The demodulation is composed into three stages: the first for bv, the second for bits, and the third employing the differential property to acquire the symbols. Note that the employed PSK makes the amplitude ambiguous such that only the phase matters.

Defect

  • In this paper, the CSI might be used for denoting the channel gain. However, the computational complexity mainly results from the analysis for delay and Doppler shifts. The computations cost for channel gain is negligible.
  • So we don’t have to consider the differential phase shift keying but the conventional M-ary phase shift keying.

Analysis of employed bits

Without considering the DPSK and up-chirps or down-chirps, the number of the bits within one symbol is rendering the fact that f(P) has a maximum point within [1, N] at . Thus, the maximum point must be located either at or at .

Comparisons

  • PSK-LoRa: Directly modulating PSKs onto single chirp which is not separated, implying log N + log M bits per symbol.
  • GCSS: Solely separating the symbols into several groups, implying bits per symbol.
  • DM-CSS: The available N symbols are divided into 2 groups, associated with 2 activation bits (1 for 1, -1 for 0), one for odds and the other for evens. Then, the 1 selection bit for up-chirp or down-chirp is used. Overall, the number of bits within one symbol is . [Simplified version of DPSK-MM-CSS]

Paper 2 - Novel Double Slope Frequency Shift Chirp Symbol

There are two encoding methods proposed in this paper. The specific depiction of the two approaches is given as follows.

  • Approach 1 - DSFSC-DCSZ symbols

    • The temporal figure is given as follows:

      where each symbol is composed of two parts, one with up-chirp and the other with down-chirp starting at 0.

  • Approach 2 - DSFSC-DCSMF symbols

The demodulation of these waveforms utilizes the temporal instruments, which is not covered.

Paper 3 - Memoryless Continuous-Phase Chirp Spread Spectrum for Mud Pulse Telemetry

This paper considers the estimation for symbol duration and bandwidth under the underwater acoustic scenario. The receiver utilizes a concatenation of algorithms to analytically acquire the corresponding estimates, given as follows.

  • Memoryloss analog nonlinear preprocessor (MANP): suppress the impact of underwater noise (thus neglected).
  • Short-time Fractional Fourier Transform (ST-FRFT): Output an time-frequency image.
  • Edge detection: Convert the color image from TF image into a gray image.
  • Hough Transform: an effective image recognition method for a gray image.
  • Parameter Estimation: Calculate all bandwidth, duration, and chirp rate. Then k-means is employed to classify these parameter sets (by solely using bandwidth).

MT C1.3 Outer Measure

Posted on 2025-07-24 Edited on 2025-08-06 In Mathematics , Measure Theory

Chapter 1.3 Outer Measure

Definition 0

An outer measure on X is a function μ* : 𝒫(X) → [0, +∞] such that

  • μ*(⌀) = 0;
  • if A ⊆ B ⊆ X, then μ*(A) ≤ μ*(B) [monotone], and
  • if {An} is an infinite sequence of subsets of X, then μ*(∪nAn) ≤ ∑nμ*(An) [countably subadditive].

Definition 1 - Lebesgue outer measure (λ*)

For each subset A of ℝ, let 𝒞A be the set of all infinite sequences {(ai, bi)} of bounded open intervals such that A ⊆ ∪i(ai, bi). Then, λ* : 𝒫(ℝ) → [0, +∞] is defined by λ*(A) = inf {∑i(bi − ai) : {(ai, bi)} ∈ 𝒞A}.

Property 1

Proposition 1.3.2. Lebesgue outer measure on ℝ is an outer measure, and it assigns to each subinterval of ℝ its length.

Proposition 1.3.4. Lebesgue outer measure on ℝd is an outer measure, and it assigns to each d-dimensional interval its volume.

Definition 2 - μ*-measurable

A subset B of X is μ*-measurable (or measurable with respect to μ*) if μ*(A) = μ*(A ∩ B) + μ*(A ∩ Bc) holds for every subset A of X.

Property 2

Proposition 1.3.5. Let X be a set, and let μ* be an outer measure on X. Then each subset B of X that satisfies μ*(B) = 0 or that satisfies μ*(Bc) = 0 is μ*-measurable.

Theorem 1.3.6. Let X be a set, let μ* be an outer measure on X, and let ℳμ* be the collection of all μ*-measurable subsets of X. Then

  • ℳμ* is a σ-algebra, and
  • the restriction of μ* to ℳμ* is a measure on ℳμ*.

Proposition 1.3.7. Every Borel subset of ℝ is Lebesgue measurable.

Proposition 1.3.8. Every Borel subset of ℝd is Lebesgue measurable.

MT C1.2 Measures

Posted on 2025-06-19 Edited on 2025-06-25 In Mathematics , Measure Theory

Chapter 1.2 Measures

Definition 1

μ : 𝒜 → [0, +∞] is said to be countably additive if and to be finitely additive if .

Then, a (countably additive) measure (or finitely additive measure) on 𝒜 is a function μ : 𝒜 → [0, +∞] that satisfies μ(⌀) = 0 and is countably (or finitely) additive.

【NOTE: In the following, the term measure is used to denote countably additive measure while the finitely additive measure will be called in full.】

Properties 1

Proposition 1.2.2 - Let (X, 𝒜, μ) be a measure space, and A, B are subsets of X that belong to 𝒜 and satisfy A ⊆ B. Then, μ(A) ≤ μ(B). If μ(A) < ∞, then μ(B − A) = μ(B) − μ(A).

Definition 2

μ is a finite measure if μ(X) < +∞ and σ-finite measure if X is the union of a sequence A1, A2, ... of sets belonging to 𝒜 and satisfy μ(Ai) < +∞ for each i.

  • Generally- A set in 𝒜 is σ-finite under μ if it is the union of a sequence of sets belonging to 𝒜 with finite measure.
  • The measure space (X, 𝒜, μ) is called finite or σ-finite if μ is finite or σ-finite.

Properties 2

Proposition 1.2.4 - Let (X, 𝒜, μ) be a measure space. If {Ak} is an arbitrary sequence of sets that belong to 𝒜, then Proposition 1.2.5 - Let (X, 𝒜, μ) be a measure space.

    1. If {Ak} is an increasing sequence of sets that belong to 𝒜, then μ(∪kAk) = limkμ(Ak).
    1. If {Ak} is a decreasing sequence of sets that belong to 𝒜, and if μ(An) < +∞ for some n, then μ(∩kAk) = limkμ(Ak).

Proposition 1.2.6 - Let (X, 𝒜) be a measurable space, and let μ be a finitely additive measure on (X, 𝒜). Then μ is a measure if either

    1. limkμ(Ak) = μ(∪kAk) holds for each increasing sequence {Ak} of sets that belong to 𝒜, or
    1. limkμ(Ak) = 0 holds for each decreasing sequence {Ak} of sets that belong to 𝒜 and satisfy ∩kAk = ⌀.

Terminology

  • A Borel measure on ℝd : A measure on (ℝd, ℬ(ℝd)).
  • A finite or σ-finite measure μ on (X, 𝒜) is continuous if μ({x}) = 0 holds for each x in X.
  • A finite or σ-finite measure μ on (X, 𝒜) is discrete if there is a countable subset D of X such that μ(Dc) = 0.

MT C1.1 Algebras and Sigma-Algebras

Posted on 2025-06-16 Edited on 2025-06-19 In Mathematics , Measure Theory

Chapter 1.1 Algebras and Sigma-Algebras

Definition

Let X be a set. Then 𝒜 is called an algebra on X if The definition above is so redundant that the removal of either (c) or (d) does not change anything.

A collection 𝒜 is a σ-algebra on X if Likewise, the conditions (a), (b), (c) or (a), (b), (d) can solely be used.

If 𝒜 is a σ-algebra on X, then a subset A of X is σ-measurable if A ∈ 𝒜.

Properties

Proposition 1.1.2 - Let X be a set. Then an intersection of an arbitrary nonempty collection of σ-algebra on X is a σ-algebra on X.

Corollary 1.1.3 - Let X be a set, and let ℱ be a family of subsets of X. Then there is a smallest σ-algebra on X that includes ℱ.

The smallest σ-algebra is called the σ-algebra generated by ℱ and is often denoted by σ(ℱ).

Borel σ-algebra on ℝd

The Borel σ-algebra is defined by the σ-algebra on X generated by the collection of open subsets of ℝd, denoted by ℬ(ℝd).【Borel subsets of ℝd are those that belong to ℬ(ℝd)】

Proposition 1.1.4 - The σ-algebra ℬ(ℝ) of Borel subsets of ℝ is generated by each of following collections of sets: Proposition 1.1.5 - The σ-algebra ℬ(ℝd) of Borel subsets of ℝd is generated by each of following collections of sets:

Some sets in ℬ(ℝd)

  • 𝒢: the family of all open subsets of ℝd.
  • ℱ: the family of all closed subsets of ℝd.
  • 𝒢δ: the collection of all intersections of sequences of sets in 𝒢.
  • ℱσ: the collection of all unions of sequences of sets in ℱ.

Proposition 1.1.6 - Each closed subset of ℝd is a Gδ, and each open subset of ℝd is an Fσ.

Definition of increasing and decreasing sequences

A sequence {Ai} of sets is called increasing if Ai ⊆ Ai + 1 holds for each i and decreasing if Ai ⊇ Ai + 1 holds for each i.

Proposition 1.1.7 - Let X be a set, and let 𝒜 be an algebra on X. Then 𝒜 is a σ-algebra if either

  1. 𝒜 is closed under the formation of unions of increasing sequences of sets, or

  2. 𝒜 is closed under the formation of intersections of decreasing sequences of sets.
